segments.text: title, leaving the legislature.
1983 was a turnaround year in many ways.
The family had been instrumental in starting a bank in College Station.
We had oil and gas revenue on our land out in the country.
and I was still chairman of the House Appropriations Committee under a new speaker.

I had not given serious consideration to leaving the legislature until I was approached by the A&M System Board of Regents about becoming their executive secretary and would be the legislative liaison to the legislature.
The more I thought about it, the more sense that it made.
I had always worked in the best interest of the system and enjoyed my relationship with the legislature.
There was also the possibility that the oil and gas revenue would suddenly dry up.
and would again put finances in a pretty tight situation.
In addition, I had served five terms as chairman of the House Appropriations Committee and began to grow somewhat weary of the
position as it required a new training program each time because there was about a 50% turnover in membership in the committee each session.

Committee members that were served on the Appropriations Committee were often tapped in the next session to serve as committee chairman and were then therefore removed from their position as a member of the Appropriations Committee.
Discussions with the Board of Regents began in earnest following the regular session of the legislature in 1983.
By late 1983, I had made a decision to leave the legislature and
accept a position with the Secretary of the Board should the Board of Regents choose to elect me.
On or about the first of November, I announced that I would not be a candidate for re-election.
Later that month, when the Board of Regents met, they tentatively approved my appointment as Executive Secretary of the Board.
It was not finally approved until the meeting in January about the same date that I assumed the position upon resigning from the legislature.
It is my understanding that at the very last minute before the board acted upon the minute order in November that
a concession was made to the Chancellor to make it a dual position, that is, Executive Secretary of the Board of Regents and Vice Chancellor for State Affairs.
By doing it this way, the Chancellor felt like that I would become a part of his staff and he would have more of a role in legislative affairs.

I never viewed it as any other way except that the Chancellor would play a very significant role in legislative affairs and could see no reason why the dual role would not work very well since it would really not change anything as far as I was concerned.
Shortly after my appointment it was suggested that I
have an office in the chancellor's suite, but I declined and suggested I would prefer not to do that.
I felt like I could operate more efficiently out of one office as opposed to two offices.

During the time I was in the legislature, I operated out of about three or four offices and found it rather inefficient to do so, although there was nothing that I could be done about that arrangement while I was in the legislature.
Other than the one conversation regarding the suggestion that I have an office in the chancellor's suite, the issue never came up again until many years later.
A resignation effective on January the 15th, 1984, forced the then Governor White to call a special election for my replacement.
At that time, there was a need for a special session dealing with public school finance,
sometime during 1984.
The election was called for during the spring break of March of 1984 and the fact that it was called during the spring break became a major issue in the campaign.
I do not know whether the governor
had any knowledge of when spring break was and the fact that the students would be out of town.
But it certainly made for an issue that fired up the student body in the general election in November later that year.
And as a result, it reversed the election results in November when the two candidates squared off for the second time.
1984 is remembered for some other reasons in addition to those already mentioned.
Earlier in 1984, there was to be a constitutional election on a proposition referred to as Proposition No.
This proposition would restructure the permanent university fund and would dedicate $200 million through the higher education assistance fund.
The higher education assistance fund would be funded through general revenue appropriations that would be automatically funded from the top, so to speak, each time the legislature met.

You will recall that the schools outside of the Permanent University Fund that did not share in the Permanent University Fund had previously shared in the 10-cent ad valorem tax that was assessed throughout the state and was about to be ruled unconstitutional.
The pure passage of Proposition 2, the Council of Governing Boards became very active.
The Council of Governing Boards was made up of the chairman of the governing boards of the institutions of higher education that were state supported.
In the case of Texas A&M,
This would have normally been H.R.
Bumbright of Dallas, but he requested that Mr. Joe Richardson of Amarillo serve in his stead on the board.
This was honored, and Mr. Richardson in turn asked me to attend all the meetings and become involved in advising them.
with regards to how to get Proposition 2 passed.
Proposition 2 did pass in November and become a part of our Constitution, thereby making some changes in the

Permanent University Fund by bringing several schools under the fund that had not previously been there and dedicating $200 million to the Higher Education Assistance Fund to take care of the schools that were not covered by the Permanent University Fund.
Generally speaking, the Permanent University Fund covered those schools that were in the University of Texas system and the Texas A&M University system.
However, we have to be very careful to point out that this did not cover future schools that might come into the system, something that we'll talk about later when the South Texas schools
became desires to enter either the A&M system or the University of Texas system.
1984, the state of Texas experienced a downturn in its economic situation.
This had a direct impact on the revenues that were to come to the state to fund state government.
On making certain projections, Governor Mark White came to the conclusion that state agencies would have to reduce their budgets by some 13% in general revenue.
Otherwise, the state would be floating in red ink somewhere in the future, sometime in the future.
The governor did not have the authority to force a 13% reduction or any reduction for that matter.
All he could do was simply ask that it be done.
Only the legislature could have enforced a reduction in the budgets of state government.
The records will probably show that most agencies and institutions gave up very little and did not reach the 13% goal that the governor had in mind.
For example, Texas A&M did better than average by giving up some 9%, all of this being in reduced utility costs, which could not be spent for anything else
the way the appropriations bill is written anyway.
The elections were adequate enough, though, to forestall a crisis between the time that the governor issued the executive order and the legislature was back in session in 1985.
Although a crisis was forestalled, another crisis was looming for higher education with regards to state appropriations.
Legislative Budget Board meets in the fall prior to the session of the legislature convening and writes a proposed budget.
And these budget numbers usually reflect an expenditure of funds that are available and allows little room for changes during the legislative session.
In the year of the fiscal crisis, it was anticipated that most of the funds would be spent prior to the at least
in the recommendations of the budget board prior to the session beginning.
State agencies generally fared pretty well in the recommendations of the budget board until it came down to making appropriations for higher education.
When those appropriations were made, it was
required that a 27% reduction be made in general revenue for institutions of higher education.
This was a much greater cut than state agencies had experienced and was a far greater cut than reduction in appropriations than
any state agency or university had ever experienced in modern times.
This sent shockwaves across the nation with regards to the terrible plight of Texas and Texas higher education.
caused me to start reflecting on what might occur during the session once the legislature convened in January of 1985.
There were two reasons for the 27% reduction for higher education on that fateful day in December 1984 by the Legislative Budget Board.
First is that it's the last major article in the appropriations bill to be considered.
Therefore, it is.

necessary that the recommendations by the staff be a balanced budget and any balancing that has to be done has to be done at the end of the appropriations process by the legislative budget board and its staff.
Second and more important
Concern and reason is that 84% of the budget is mandated either by statute, federal mandate, or by court order, leaving only 16% of the budget that is not mandated.
16% is significant until you consider the fact that virtually all of the non-mandated appropriations
is in higher education.

To compound the of major concern was the fact that most legislators were not aware that such recommendations would be forthcoming once they convened in Austin and the appropriations recommendations were laid out.
This lack of awareness
concern to me about as much as anything else.
When I considered the people that would be the key players in the appropriations process, I could predict as anyone could

who the major players would be in the Senate and in the House with the exception of the person that served as Chairman of Budget and Oversight in the House Higher Education Committee and would serve on the Appropriations Committee as a member of the Budget, Chairman of the Budget and Oversight from Higher Education.
This is the person that you look to to be the one to champion higher education.
This became critically important when you consider the budget reductions that were going to be in the recommendations of the budget board.
When I considered the possibilities
whom I could fill that role since the position would be someone new.
I could only come up with one person that had the knowledge and the savvy of the legislative operations and the courage to sit with the
chairman of the Appropriations Committee and to stand up to the Speaker and say that higher education should not be mistreated.
The next question, and more importantly, was how we could get the Speaker of the House to make such an appointment.
It occurred to me that there was one person that could influence the speaker more than anyone else in the whole state of Texas.
He happened to be a graduate of Texas A&M and was a close friend of the chancellor of Texas A&M University's system.
So I asked the chancellor if he would call this individual.
and urge him to contact the Speaker and urge the Speaker to make the appointment of this individual to the Chairman of Budget and Oversight for Higher Education.
The appointment was made by the Speaker, much to our delight, and it wasn't until months later
that it was confirmed that the appointment was made because of the phone calls that were made.
Confirmed one day about midway in the session when the Speaker of the House stopped me in the hallway and said, you Aggies really play tough.
And I knew exactly what he had reference to when he made that statement.
He said, I know what happened.
And he said, I just want you to know you Aggies sure do play tough.

With a champion of higher education in a key slot, we were able to restore all but about 9% or 10% of the budget reductions that had been made by the recommended, at least by the Legislative Budget Board.

The restoration of these funds to the extent that they were made was due to the effort of many, but it was very critical to have someone sitting on the committee that could not only relate to the chairman of the Appropriations Committee and the speaker,
but was willing to stand up to them when the time came.

Efforts were monumental on the part of the chairman of the Board of Regents of the University of Texas System who held a series of meetings in the evenings to rally support and to tell our story to the members of the legislature.
I was invited to attend each and every one of those meetings and
They were extremely effective and could not have been handled better than the chairman of the UT Board of Regents was able to handle them.
To address the fiscal crisis, one of the approaches that was used to
try to restore some physical integrity to higher education was to prepare alternative proposals for higher education.

It became the University of Texas system's role to prepare these alternative proposals and take them to the key people in the legislature that were writing the higher education budget and tried to sell them on the IIDF.
This set a pattern for years to come of the University of Texas preparing alternative proposals that
would be to deal with all of higher education as a package as opposed to each institution going in and making a plea individually with regards to its appropriations.
One of the problems and challenges that I always had to deal with when these proposals came forward
before they were taken to members of the legislature, was trying to reconcile the appropriations for our A&M services, our agencies.
The University of Texas system did not understand our agencies and were not that concerned and had difficulty in proposing what I considered a
bare budget for these agencies.
Each time we were successful in getting the University of Texas system to reconsider their proposal and add funds to the agencies' budgets prior to submitting them to members of the legislature.
There were other distractions that we had to deal with in early 1985 when the session of the legislature was well underway.
It caused great concern.

was the Comptroller of Public Accounts pronouncing that higher education had a $2 billion gravy bowl of funds that it could spend to make up the deficit that we contended that would exist if we did not get more general revenue appropriations.
It took some time and effort to convince members of the legislature that the Comptroller was
not on target in suggesting these funds could be spent in such a manner.
These funds were out of special funds, special appropriations, or special grants that had been made to universities for scholarships and for various and other sundry purposes.
programs and could not be diverted to general revenue appropriations to take care of operating budgets of universities.
Another funding issue was to get implemented the changes brought about by Proposition 2 that had been made a part of the Texas Constitution.
There were several issues that called for additional expenditure of general revenue funds in Proposition 2.
First and foremost was a $200 million appropriation that would go to the schools outside of the permanent university fund, and this was called the Higher Education Assistance Fund.
These funds had to be set aside out of the general revenue appropriation's
prior to any operating budgets being allocated funds.
In addition, some other changes that were made in Proposition 2 dealt with the allocation of additional funds to Prairie View.
$6 million each year for the next 10 years to come from the University of Texas System's portion of the Permanent University Fund, and with A&M providing an equitable portion.
That was in 1985 when it became...
first became law as a part of the Constitution.
And since then, University of Texas has completed its obligation of providing $6 million for 10 years.
But to my knowledge, we still have not clearly defined what is an equitable portion for Prairie View.
The other changes that were made was the addition of other schools under the permanent university fund.
In the case of the Texas A&M University system, we were adding the Texas A&M University at Galveston.
It also made a change with regards to allocation of funds to our agencies in the Texas A&M University system.
In the past, the A&M agencies had to get legislative approval to sell bonds and use bond proceeds for construction at facilities other than on the A&M campus at College Station.
This proposition changed that where the allocation and approval could be made by the A&M System Board of Regents.
A final change brought about by Proposition 2 in 1984 was providing access
of the system offices of the Texas A&M University System and the University of Texas System to the available university fund for their operational expenses.
This provision in the proposition has obviously led to a decline in
the availability of general revenue appropriations by the legislature to the system offices.
Since proposition to system offices of A&M and the University of Texas system have received only a token amount of general revenue appropriations from the legislature.
Mentioned before 1985, the legislative session

presented some very difficult times for higher education because of the budgetary cuts going into the session and coming out of the session with still about a nine percent reduction in general revenue appropriations for higher education.
The actions that was taken by the Texas A&M University System Board of Regents to alleviate some of the
problem, particularly on the main campus of Texas A&M University, was to refund most of the bonds that had been previously funded at higher rates.
than the interest rates that were prevailing in 1985 and 1986.
Refunding these bonds, about $50 million was freed up for one-time funding by the Texas A&M University System Board of Regents.
The regent chiefly responsible for this
idea and concept was the chairman of the board of regents at that time, David Eller.

Chairman Eller had an excellent grasp of bond financing and was able to walk through with the other regents the complexities of refunding the bonds and how this was advantageous to the Texas A&M University system.
In 1987, when the legislature convened that January, the leadership in the legislature and in the governor's office remained the same.
Jim Lewis was still speaker.
Bill Hobby was the lieutenant governor.
Grant Jones chaired the Senate Finance Committee and Jim Rudd was chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.
State Representative Tom Muher was still the chairman of Budget and Oversight and sat on the Appropriations Committee representing higher education.
There were several issues that arose during the session that were not contemplated prior to the session convening.
Early in the session, I was contacted by State Representative Eddie Cavazos, who represented the Corpus Christi area.
And he advised me that he would like to see Corpus Christi
state university become a part of the Texas A&M University system.
I suspect that Representative Cavazos' ulterior motive was to make Corpus Christi State University a four-year institution.
At that time, it was an upper-level institution and had only juniors, seniors, and graduate students.

Apparently Representative Cavazos was talking to the University of Texas system at the same time and had been promised through that system's chairman of the Board of Regents that he would see to it that a new institution was created in South Texas to
alleviate the lack of higher education in the South Texas area.
Cavazos seemed to like this idea, and I had little contact with him after the University of Texas board chairman intervened.
At that time, the Texas A&M University system was not taking an aggressive position with regards to bringing Corpus Christi State University into the Texas A&M University system.
Cavazos introduced a resolution that called for the University of Texas to do an interim study
to determine the need for a new university in the South Texas area.
The resolution, when it reached the Senate, was handled by the Corpus Christi Senator, Carlos Trujan.
Senator Trujan, being a friend personally and a friend of Texas A&M, contacted me

and suggested that he wish to add the Texas A&M University System to the resolution and create a joint committee of the House and Senate that would use the resources of the University of Texas System and the Texas A&M University System to make the study to determine the needs for higher education in South Texas.
This version passed by the Senate was accepted by the House and became the final version of the resolution creating the joint committee to study higher education in South Texas.
I will have much more to say about the interim study at a later time.
but first to complete the issues that were brought before the 1987 legislative session.
Prior to 1987, a select committee on higher education chaired by Mr. Larry Temple, who was a former press agent for President Johnson,
and chairman of the Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board, had completed its work and submitted its recommendations in the form of a comprehensive bill that was before the legislature.
There were several positive aspects with regards to the bill that the select committee
had drawn up and introduced in the session that is having a lasting impact is the drafting of the General Appropriations Act in such a way that higher education is virtually veto-proof.
In the past, one of the favorite veto items
of the governor was special items in higher education.
1987, with the passage of the recommendations of the Select Committee on Higher Education, these items are now veto proof.
item that caused some concern within the Texas A&M University system dealt with the handling of indirect costs from federal projects, primarily research projects.
Past practice of the legislature in handling indirect costs through the appropriations process was to
capture those costs from universities and bring them into the appropriations process.
This, in effect, did not allow the universities to retain any of the indirect costs that were received on federal grants and federal projects.
On the other hand, the agencies within the Texas A&M University system were allowed to retain 100% of their indirect costs.
That is, they were not captured by the appropriations process and freed up those funds for whatever use the agencies wished to make.
It was advantageous to the agencies in two respects.
Number one, it meant that they had more funds to work with, and number two, they had more flexibility with the indirect cost funds than they had with general revenue appropriations.
The Select Committee on Higher Education had recommended that universities
be allowed to retain 50% of the indirect costs on federal grants.
In drafting the bill, however, they used the language, quote, institutions of higher education, close quote, were to retain 50% of their indirect costs that they
recovered from federal projects.
I was unable to get the language changed so that our state agencies were not included in that particular definition where the term institutions of higher education was used.
In the Senate, however, I was able to prevail upon Senator Chad Edwards to change that particular wording to general academic and health science institutions.
This clearly excluded the state agencies at the Texas A&M University system from losing 50% of their indirect costs.
One of the concerns was discussing this issue in public view because of the misunderstanding that would likely prevail.
When the conference committee was deliberating on the bill,

I was called back to the Lieutenant Governor's office in a private meeting with three or four people from higher education, instructed by the Lieutenant Governor that the last few issues were to be resolved before we left the room.
As more and more of the issues were resolved,
members of higher education began to drift away from the table until the only ones left was the representative of the University of Texas system and myself.
We waited until that time to explain why we wanted the language to read general academic and health science institutions.

at the University of Texas System representatives to agree to use that language and as a result we never had to explain it to the legislature as a whole or to even individual members of the legislature other than Senator Edwards.

Discussed it with the sponsor in the house but was unable to prevail upon him to make the change and for that reason we found ourselves in conference committee with the house version relating to 50% retention of indirect costs for institutions of higher education which would include the
A&M agencies or services, the Senate version being silent with regards to the A&M services or agencies, which was the preferred language as far as the A&M system was concerned.
Our strategy of avoiding making it a public issue with regards to the A&M services I think
has paid great dividends over the years.
A final issue that the 1987 regular session of the Texas legislature dealt with was related to the Texas A&M University at Galveston.
This was a bill introduced by Senator Chet Brooks, who was a ranking senator and on the conference committee of the General Appropriations Act.
At the time, the bill was moving through the legislature.

Although I was never told this, I'm sure that the bill was introduced by Senator Brooks at the request of the president of Texas A&M University at Galveston, who had a reputation of bypassing the system office and the Board of Regents when he wished to accomplish something through the legislature.
Fortunately, once Senator Brooks had filed the bill in the Senate, I got a call from his office requesting that I come by and look over the bill and see if I had any changes that I wished to make.
Since the bill had been filed, this meant that a complete substitute would be written
and taken to committee, Senate committee, if there were any changes that needed to be made.
The bill as drawn, in my opinion, would have taken Texas A&M University Galveston from under the control of Texas A&M University.
As Secretary of the Board of Regents, I was aware of the fact that the Board did not want to see that happen, and if anything, wanted to bring it more under control of Texas A&M University.
I seriously doubted that the bill would pass, since it was introduced very late in the session, but we did not want to take any chances.

I was allowed to rewrite the bill in such a way that it came even more under control of Texas A&M University and was able to also consult with the president-to-be of Texas A&M University, Galveston, who at the time was living in Washington, D.C.
It was not surprising because of the
seniority of Senator Brooks that the bill passed in the Senate.
Surprising, however, that the state representative representing the Galveston area was able to pass it in the House very quickly and the bill became law.
